description.narrative:
''Public Private Development Partnership for Renewable Energy Skills Training and Women Economic Empowerment in Somalia" är ett program som sträcker sig över fyra år 2018-2022, inklusive en 6-månaders startfas. Programmet kommer att inrikta sig på två övergripande mål 1) Förbättrade tekniska kunskaper för att driva solenergi i Somalia och på så sätt öka marknaden samt tillgången till energi till fattiga och 2) Ökad andel kvinnor med stärkt ekonomiskt egenmakt i Somalia. För att uppnå dessa mål har ILO föreslagit att följande specifika aktiviteter (delmål) genomförs a) förbättra förvaltningen samt samordningen inom energisektorn, b) bidra till kompetensutveckling inom sektorn för förnybar energi för att öka tillgängligheten och svara mot nuvarande och framtida marknadsbehov c) förbättra arbetsmöjligheter inom energisektorn d) förbättra kvinnors roll inom energisektorn och särkskilt förnybar energi. e) öka efterfrågan på förnybara energiprodukter, och f) förbättra den långsiktiga kapaciteten och hållbarheten hos civila samhällsorganisationen i Somalia.
Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att genomföras i samarbete med somaliska företag, civila samhällsorganisationer, den svenska handelskammaren, den amerikanska handelskammaren, arbets- och socialdepartementet, energidepartementet, utbildningsdepartementet samt handelsdepartementet i Somalia. Programmet kommer att föregås av en sex månaders startperiod för att kunna färdigställa förberedande aktiviteter som kommer att underlätta implementeringen av insatsen.
Sida har en total budget på SEK 49,6 miljoner. Ungefär SEK 12,2 miljoner av budgeten kommer att överföras till ILO:s samarbetspartners för att genomföra en del av projektverksamheten. Den totala programbudgeten kommer att utvecklas under startfasen där bidrag från berörda samarbetsaktörer kommer att inkluderas både i form av medel och som egen insats.

The International Labour Organisation (ILO) has applied to Sida for funding of 49.6 million SEK to carry out the ‘Public Private Development Partnership for Renewable Energy Skills Training and Women’s Economic Empowerment in Somalia during the period 2018-2022.
The intervention will aim at two goals 1) Improved technical skills to drive solar technology deployment in Somalia in order to grow the market and raise energy access to the poor and 2) Increased proportion of economically empowered women in Somalia. To achieve the above mentioned goals, ILO has proposed to specifically; a) improve management and coordination within the power sector; b) contribute to skills development for the renewable energy sector that is available and responds to current and future market needs; c) improve integration of Somalis in the energy sector workforce; d) enhance the role of women in emerging renewable energy market; e) increase demand for renewable energy products; f) improve the long-term capacity and sustainability of Somali Civil Society Organizations and g) Strengthen the ability of women to advocate for policy and regulatory reforms.
The proposed intervention will be implemented in partnership with select Somali private companies, civil society organizations, Chamber of Trade Sweden, Chamber of Commerce and, the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs as well as the Ministry of Education. The programme will be preceded by a six month inception phase.
The intervention has a total budget of 49.6 MSEK which will be wholly funded by Sweden. Approximately 12.2 MSEK of the budget will be forwarded to partners to implemented part of the project activities.

This training programme takes a multi-faceted approach with the overall objective of increasing technical skills in the electricity and renewable energy sector in Somalia and consequently enabling deployment of renewable energy throughout the country. The intervention also aims to economically empower women in Somalia.

description.narrative:
The program has two thematic focuses: renewable energy and womens economic empowerment. The theory of change is premised that expanding energy access in the country has the potential to increase the productivity and competitiveness of Somali businesses, contribute to alleviating poverty. While Womens Economic Empowerment gives women the independence, confidence, and ability to transform their lives. The program hopes to reach 805 students of which 161 are women with renewable energy skills trainings and 500 Growth-Oriented Women Entrepreneurs (GOWEs). This report covers the project implementation period between 1st of January to 31st December 2019. The period was characterised with review of the program document and budget following 6months inception period. Much of the time spent reviewing and approving the final program document, further developing the annual workplan and budget for the year 2019.
Renewable Energy Component Under the Renewable Energy component, the program was able to select program partners and stakeholder consultations between ILO, Benadir State, Puntland and private sector. These consultations yielded in-kind support from the private sector of USD 1,740,000 which is (58%) of SIDAs contributing of USD 2,984,398 for the renewable energy component. Basic curriculum for electrical services was developed and endorsed by the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs and the private sector companies. Review of solar PV curricula (tier 1-3) with industry representatives and potential adaptation to Somalia context was completed. The curriculum was developed through partnerships with ILO Decent work team and Strathmore Energy Research Centre (SERC) and Kenya Powers Institute for Energy Studies and Research (IESR). The curriculum includes power generation, transmission, distribution, building services and occupational safety, health, labour and gender. The relevant assessments and certification tools were developed and adopted by the relevant ministries in the Federal Government of Somalia. The project further evaluated existing training facilities and BECO in Mogadishu and NECSOM in Garowe were selected to provide training facilities; pervade job placement and apprenticeships. 20 participants (16 male and 4 Female) were identified from the private sector companies to attend TOTs for the curriculums developed. The private sector companies identified further beneficiaries of 455 students (68 women and 387 men) who will be the first caseload to be trained in 2020.
Women Economic Empowerment On the Womens Economic Empowerment component, the project identified 100 Business Development Services Providers (BDSPs) and Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) in Mogadishu and Garowe. These organizations and freelancers are going to benefit from the project interventions in order to build their financial, technical and organizational sustainability, with the aim to contribute to a stronger and gender responsive entrepreneurship ecosystem in Somalia that does not always survive through technical and financial assistance from development actors. The starting point was the introduction of the Womens Entrepreneurship self-assessment (WE check), formerly known as FAMOS Check, an organizational self-assessment tool that guides public and private, financial and non-financial BDSPs to conduct a systematic self-assessment of the extent to which they target and serve women entrepreneurs, as a means to improve their performance and enhance their impact and sustainability. The project supported one BDSP, One Earth Future (OEF) to conduct this process in two of their programmes in Somalia: Shuraako and Secure Fisheries. Furthermore, the project initiated the sectoral assessment of womens entrepreneurship development (WED assessment) in the agriculture and renewable energy sectors to identify value chains conducive to women's economic empowerment in terms of job creation opportunities and socioeconomic transformation.
In addition, the project trained 23 trainers (of which 8 are women) in the Start and Improve your Business (SIYB) entrepreneurship training progamme and 25 trainers (of which 5 are women) in Improve Your Exhibiting Skills (IYES). SIYB is a system of interrelated training packages and supporting materials that respond to stages of business development. Improve Your Business (IYB) package of SIYB enables existing entrepreneurs to develop their skills and improvement plans in buying, stock control, marketing, costing, record keeping, business planning and human resource management. IYES is a marketing tool aims at optimizing GOWEs participation in fair trades and exhibitions, including proper utilization of e-platforms and social media for marketing and business development purposes. The trainers will replicate the training to selected GOWEs depending on their needs. They will also be supported to organize themselves into networks of trainers (for those who will be certified) so that they can launch different initiatives to boost the SME sector in various locations across Somalia. Three Technical Working Group meetings (TWG) were held, two of the TWG meetings for the renewable energy component held on August 18, 2019 and October 13, 2019 and the other was for Womens Economic Empowerment Component held on September 11, 2019. These technical working groups guided the project implementation and acted as an advisory board the project Steering Committee. The first Project Steering Committee (PSC) meeting was held on 10th December 2019. It was attended by all relevant line miniseries; Ministry of Women and Human Rights development, Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, Sweden and all other key stakeholders including key private sector partners and employer and workers organizations.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
